questions.question_text: Where is vSphere Client Service health viewed?

discussion.content: its VAMI correct answer is A.
No, A would be vCenter service health. Unless question is at fault, answer is D

comments.content: the health status of the "VMware vSphere Client" service is only visible in the VAMI

vSphere Client is a vCenter service, hence it's in VAMI.

I think you mistook it for Host Client which is for esxi

questions.question_text: Which VMware solution provides integrated cloud infrastructure and cloud management services for VMware Cloud on AWS?

discussion.content:
correct answer
VMware Cloud Foundation makes it easy to deploy and run a hybrid cloud. VMware Cloud Foundation provides integrated cloud infrastructure (compute, storage, networking, and security) and cloud management services to run enterprise applications in both private and public environments.

VMware Cloud Director is a leading cloud service-delivery platform used by some of the world's most popular cloud providers to operate and manage successful
VMware Cloud Foundation is the hybrid cloud platform for managing VMs and orchestrating containers, built on full-stack hyperconverged infrastructure (HCI)
VMware vCloud® Automation Center™ empowers IT to accelerate the delivery and ongoing management of personalized, business-relevant infrastructure
Link your private cloud with public clouds and manage them as a single hybrid environment. Free download of vCloud Connector

To use a TPM 2.0 chip, your vCenter Server environment must meet these requirements:
*vCenter Server 6.7
*ESXi 6.7 host with TPM 2.0 chip installed and enabled in UEFI
*UEFI Secure Boot enabled
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-10F7022C-DBE1-47A2-BD86-3840C6955057.html

questions.question_text: Which two options ensure all ESXi servers are protected from unsigned code? (Choose two.)
What are two requirements to deploy VMware Site Recovery Manager? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A&C
SRM need replicate Datastore

D not correct because SRM have support 6.0 later

choices.C: host-based replication through vSphere Replication or preconfigured array-based replication
choices.B: Identical storage at the protected site and at the recovery site
choices.A: vCenter Server installed at the protected site and at the recovery site
choices.E: identical ESXi versions installed at the protected site and at the recovery site
choices.D: identical vCenter Server versions installed at the protected site and at the recovery site

choices.A: NX/XD bit enabled for the CPU in the BIOS

questions.question_text: What is a requirement when installing ESXi 6.7?

discussion.content:
ESXi 6.7 requires the NX/XD bit to be enabled for the CPU in the BIOS.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.esxi.install.doc/GUID-DEB8086A-306B-4239-BF76-E354679202FC.html#:~:text=ESXi%206.7%20requires%20a%20minimum,be%20enabled%20on%20x64%20CPUs.

ESXi 6.7 requires a host machine with at least two CPU cores.
ESXi 6.7 supports 64-bit x86 processors released after September 2006. This includes a broad range of multi-core processors. For a complete list of supported processors, see the VMware compatibility guide at http://www.vmware.com/resources/compatibility.
ESXi 6.7 requires the NX/XD bit to be enabled for the CPU in the BIOS.
ESXi 6.7 requires a minimum of 4 GB of physical RAM. It is recommended to provide at least 8 GB of RAM to run virtual machines in typical production environments.
